title: Small GIF in signature marked as attachment when sent via gmail
content:
Hi all,

I've been using Eudora for almost 30 years but from time to time checked Thunderbird too because Eudora was discontinued in 2006. so I have to use the OAUTH proxy running on another computer in local network.

I have now installed Thunderbird 141.0 and configured IMAP accounts for one email account I have since Yahoo! Mail's first days in 1997. and the one I have since gmail's first days in 2004.

Everything seems to be working correctly but there is one thing I can't figure out why it is happening.

I have the same signature containing an 18x18 pixel .gif configured in both Eudora and Thunderbird and they both display correctly on the recipient's side and on gmail's webmail.

The problem is - every such an email sent by Thunderbird is at gmail's webmail recognized as "containing attachment" and is marked with a paperclip icon which is not the case when email is sent with Eudora.

The consequence is - it now looks on the gmail's webmail as every single email that I ever send via Thunderbird has an attachment which prevents noticing the messages that really do have an attachment.

I don't see any way of inserting code tags here on the forum to post the HTML code of the signatures sent by Eudora and by Thunderbird once the email arrives into gmail's Sent folder so I am sending the screenshot.

The upper HTML is how signature looks like in online gmail's Sent mailbox > Show Original when sent by Eudora and below there is how it looks like when sent by Thunderbird.

And here is the pastebin of the same HTML code: https://pastebin.com/4YHnNctC

HTML files attached as a signature to Eudora and Thunderbird: https://pastebin.com/17NuE1SY

I do NOT want to use an image from online URL with moz-do-not-send="true" tag. I want to use the .gif file from my hard disk sent in such a way it wouldn't be (by gmail's webmail) marked as an attachment and in a such way the image used for signature would be part of the message body - exactly what works well when using Eudora.

When the message is downloaded for offline reading the image used in the signature should NOT be "remote content", it should be part of the message.
creator: Chupo_cro

The server may be unavailable or is refusing SMTP connections. Please verify that your outgoing server (SMTP) settings are correct and try again.

title: How can I back up all my emails from an IMAP server to my computer?
content: The easiest and most secure way to back up your emails from any IMAP server (like Gmail, Yahoo, Outlook.com, etc.) is by using a reliable tool like MailsDaddy IMAP Backup Tool. It allows you to connect to your IMAP account and export all emails into multiple formats like PST, MBOX, EML, MSG, and others. You don’t need Outlook installed, and the tool preserves the original folder structure and attachments during export.

title: Thunderbird constantly asks for password after enabling 2FA on web.de/gmx.de
content:
Hi everyone, since I enabled two-factor authentication (2FA) on my email accounts at web.de and gmx.de, I can no longer use these accounts reliably in Mozilla Thunderbird.

I set up the accounts using an application-specific password (a so-called "one-time password"), as provided by web.de/gmx.de when 2FA is active. The initial setup works, and I can send and receive emails for a short time. But shortly after, Thunderbird asks me for a new password again — and this keeps repeating.

I also tried using my regular account password, but of course that doesn’t work either, since Thunderbird has no way of entering the second authentication step required by 2FA.

Interestingly, everything works fine on my smartphone with the Bluemail app. There I can use the application-specific password permanently without any issues.

Does anyone have an idea what's going on? Could it be that Thunderbird doesn’t properly store or maintain sessions for app passwords? Or is there another workaround?

Thanks in advance!

Technical details (unchanged during setup): Incoming Mail: Server type: IMAP Server: imap.web.de Port: 993 Security: SSL/TLS Authentication method: Normal password

Outgoing Mail: SMTP server: smtp.web.de Port: 587 Security: STARTTLS Authentication method: Normal password
creator: julianw000

title: My emails have disappeared!
content: I have recently been deleting some old emails from my Thunderbird account in my Windows 10 pc, prior to moving on to a new Windows 11 pc. Suddenly, all my email folders are still there in the left hand column, but when I click on the Folder, which perhaps says there are 400 messages, nothing appears. I have tried the Repair but that hasn't worked. I am an elderly lady (81), and have been using Thunderbird for many, many years, so I have saved emails from a long time ago, that I would hate to lose. I still hear the sound when a message arrives in my Inbox and the number increases by one, but no message? I'm desperately in need of some straightforward advice to solve this problem. The only way I can read new emails now, is on my new computer, or on my iPad.
creator: janehagger7

title: Background has turned white
content: Windows 10 on PC with Thunderbird 140.1.0esr (64-bit) Since the last update, the background on my Tbird messages list, email panel and in my compose email panel have turned from my eye-friendly light grey to glaring white and this is literally causing me a headache and a "flimmer" in my eyes (common in people with blue eyes). All other programs in Windows show me the light grey background as they should, it's Thunderbird itself which isn't picking up the light grey. The only place in all the tools and settings menus that I was able to find ANYTHING about background colour was (three bars) -> tools -> Settings -> HTML Style [ ] Use reader's default colours <- makes no difference whether this box is marked or not Beneath that: Text Colour is set to black. Background colour is set to light grey. There is no way to Save the settings page, so one presumes they are automatically saved. Restart (done several times) Thunderbird - still this blasted white background. I do not use HTML for emails, I use plain text. Could someone please tell me how I can get my light grey background back ?
creator: Helvetica

title: Thunderbird crashes when attaching file with Attach button - Win 7, Version 102.
content:
When I try to attach a file to an e-mail by clicking the "Attach" button, Thunderbird crashes. I can attach documents by dragging and dropping. This problem has not occurred with earlier versions of Thunderbird.

I have found two possible solutions in researching this problem: - One has to do with ensuring that my antivirus software is not scanning the outgoing e-mail. I have verified that my anti-virus software does NOT verify any e-mails, outgoing or incoming. - The other suggests that Thunderbird may be looking for a default attachment location that is on a network or in another location that may be unavailable. I am certain that this is not the case, although I do not know how to find out where (if anywhere) Thunderbird may be looking. Please help.

Windows 7 x64 Thunderbird version 102.15.1 (64-bit) Note: I have tried version 115 on my computer, but it is so slow as to be unusable. I have downgraded to version 102 and find that it works very well for me. Therefore I would prefer not to upgrade from this version.

TIA for any help Les
